constraints_details.constraints_layer_description: SASC Name: Strategic Area of Special Character
AAS Name: Area of Archaeological Significance

AIRCZ Type: AIRPORTDescription: Heathrow Planning Consultation Zone: All buildings, structures, erections and works exceeding 90 metres in height (295.3 feet)Contact: The Safeguarding Department, Heathrow Airport Limited, c/o Planning Services, First Point, Buckingham Gate, Gatwick Airport, West Sussex, RH6 0NT

description: Demolition of existing dwellinghouse and erection of two storey dwellinghouse with single storey guest annexe in garden.
decision_conditions: The vehicle parking space shown on the approved plans shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the first occupation of development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times. Reason: To ensure adequate on-site parking provision in the interests of highway safety, convenience and amenity, in accordance with CS 7 (Managing Vehicle Use) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The guest annexe hereby approved shall be used for purposes ancillary to the main dwellinghouse. The main dwellinghouse hereby approved shall remain in use as a single dwelling house and the guest annexe shall not be used, sold or sub-let as a separate dwelling. Reason: A separate unit of accommodation of this nature may not be acceptable in this location in the interests of the amenities, character of the area and highway safety in accordance with Core Strategy Policy DM10 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall begin before the expiration of three years from the date of this permission.Reason:  As required  by Section 91 of  the Town  and Country Planning  Act  1990,  as amended by Section 51 of the Planning and Compulsory Purchase Act 2004.

No development shall take place including any works of demolition until a construction method statement has been submitted to and been approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved plan/statement shall be adhered to throughout the construction period. The statement shall provide for:(a) Provision for loading/unloading materials.(b) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles.(c) Temporary site access.(d) Signing system for works traffic.(e) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works.(f) Location of all ancillary site buildings.(g) Measures to protect any tree, shrubbery and other landscape features to be retained on the site during the course of development.(h) Means of enclosure of the site.(i) Wheel washing equipment. (j) The parking of vehicles of the site operatives and visitors(k) The erection and maintenance of security hoarding.The demolition and construction of the development shall be carried out in accordance with the construction method statement so agreed.Reason:  These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

A sample of the facing materials to be utilised in the development hereby permitted shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before any works on site are commenced. The development shall  then be built in accordance with these approved samples.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby approved shall not commence until a Sustainable Drainage Strategy and associated detailed design, management and maintenance plan of surface water drainage for the site using Suds methods has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority. The approved drainage system shall be implemented in accordancewith the approved Sustainable Drainage Strategy prior to the first occupation of the dwelling and maintained thereafter for the lifetime of the development.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset and to prevent the increased risk of flooding by ensuring the provision of a satisfactory means of surface water disposal is incorporated into the design and the build of the proposed development, in accordance with Policies 5.2 and 5.3 of the London Plan (2016) and Policy DM1 of the Core Strategy Adopted (2012).

Before the development hereby permitted is commenced, written confirmation from the appointed building control body shall be submitted to demonstrate  that the specifications for the proposed dwelling meet the standard of Category 2 of the Approved Document M of the Building Regulations (2015). The development shall be carried out in accordance with the details thereby approved by the appointed building control body.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the details would affect subsequent design of other elements of the scheme and must be agreed at the outset to ensure the development complies with Policy 3.8 of the London Plan (2016).

No work relating to the development hereby approved, including works of demolition or preparation prior to building operations, shall take place other than between the hours of 08:00 and 18:00 Monday to Friday and 08:00 to 13:00 Saturdays and at no time on Sundays or Bank or National Holidays. Reason: To protect the occupiers of neighbouring properties from noise and disturbance outside the permitted hours during the construction period, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to damp proof course level of the development hereby approved, a plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority indicating the positions, design, materials and type of all gates, boundary treatment, fences and means of enclosures to be erected.  The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved plan before the building is occupied.Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and in the interest of visual amenity, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The development hereby permitted shall be strictly carried out in accordance with the approved document titled BS 5837:2012 Tree Survey, Arboricultural Impact Assessment, Tree Constraints Plan, Arboricultural Method Statement and Tree Protection Plan   received by the local planning authority on 18th March 2020. Reason: To prevent unnecessary damage occurring to the trees during building operations, thereby safeguarding the visual amenities of the site in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to damp proof course level of the development hereby approved, a landscaping scheme including details of two replacement trees shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  The approved scheme shall be implemented within the first planting season following completion of the development and the tree planting and landscaping shall thereafter be maintained for five years to the satisfaction of the Local Planning Authority.  Any trees or shrubs which die during this period shall be replaced in the first available planting season, and the area shown to be landscaped shall be permanently retained for that purpose only.  Reason: In the interests of visual amenity and also that the Local Planning Authority shall be satisfied as to the details of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the occupation of the development hereby approved, a plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority indicating the positions, design, dimensions of the cycle parking facilities and made  available for use prior to the first occupation of the development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to the the occupation of the development hereby approved, a plan shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority indicating the positions, design, dimensions of the bin storage facilities and made  available for use prior to the first occupation of the development and shall thereafter be retained for this use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of adequate cycling facilities in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, evidence showing that the development has achieved at least a 19% improvement in CO2 emissions versus Part L of the Building Regulations and internal water usage rates of no greater than 110 litres per person per day maximum water consumption (to include a fixed factor of water for outdoor use of 5 litres per person per day) have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. Reason: In the interests of sustainability and energy conservation, in accordance with policy 5.2 of the London Plan 2016 and policies CS1, DM3 and DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy 2012.

Before the beneficial occupation of the development hereby permitted, the referenced windows shall be constructed so that no part of the framework less than 1.7m above finished floor level shall be openable.  Any part below that level shall be fitted with, and retained in, obscure glazing to a minimum of level 3 on the standard scale. The referenced windows are as follows:a) All of the windows shown on approved drawing number 1811-020-Cb) All of the first floor windows shown on approved drawing numbers 1811-019-B and g 1811-018-E Any film used to achieve the requisite obscurity level shall be non-perishable and tamper-proof, and shall be replaced immediately in the event that it ceases to result in obscurity to level 3.  Reason:  To safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers, in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no windows or other openings (other than those hereby approved) shall be formed in the walls of the dwelling houses hereby approved without the prior written consent of the Local Planning Authority. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Notwithstanding the provisions of Part 1 of Schedule 2 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (or any Order revoking or re-enacting this Order) no extensions (including conservatories, porches, roof extensions and outbuildings) to the building hereby approved shall be erected within the site curtilage. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the occupiers of the adjoining residential properties and safeguard the cohesive appearance of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The single storey flat roof of the dwelling hereby permitted shall not be converted or used as a balcony or a sitting out area, and no access shall be gained except for maintenance purposes. Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted  (2012).Reason: To protect the amenities and privacy of the adjoining residential properties in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.8 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings. DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the proposed hip-to-gable roof extensions would not necessarily adhere to recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, officers note that the proposed extension could be constructed under permitted development. Further, while the proposed rear dormer roof extension would not strictly adhere to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD, in terms of set in from the side roof slope, it would be set in from the eaves and ridge of the roof slope and would appear a proportionate addition to the original dwelling, given that similar extensions are viewed in the immediate vicinity, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the siting of the proposed development in relation to the neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light/sunlight. While an opening is proposed to the side elevation at second floor level, given that it is proposed to be obscure glazed officers consider that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of loss of privacy. In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.22 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received. The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and, - The impact of the development on flood risk and drainage.Recent planning permission 21/00059/HOU is also material to the assessment of these proposals.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the proposed single storey rear extension would not strictly adhere to the requirements of the Residential Design SPD, in terms of depth, it would have an appropriate height and as such would not appear out of proportion to the dwelling house. It is is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. The proposed front porch extension is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. While the proposed two storey side extension would not be set in from the shared boundary, it would have an appropriate roof that would be set down substantially from the ridge and set back from the front elevation at first floor level. As such officers consider that on balance it would be acceptable. In addition, officers note that similar extensions can be found in the immediate vicinity and therefore the proposals in this case would not appear out of keeping with the character and appearance of the surrounding area.AmenityPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the modest scale and siting of the proposed development in relation to neighbouring properties, and that no windows are proposed to the side elevation, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: While the proposal would include the demolition of the existing garage, officers note that the width of the existing garage would not conform to modern day internal dimensions as set out in the Residential Design SPD, and as such officers consider that there would be change to the provision of on-site parking. London Plan policy T5 requires all development to include provision for cycle parking. While it is not clear from the plans where this would be accommodated, particularly due to the loss of the side access to the rear of the property, officers consider that further details could be ensured via condition to ensure compliance.Therefore, the proposal is considered not to have an adverse impact upon car parking provision, traffic congestion or highway safety, in compliance with Policy DM9 and DM10.Flood Risk AssessmentThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk assessment states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The application site is located on the south side of Jubilee a short distance to the west of the junction of Kingston Road.The surrounding area is mixed in use. The site is not in a conservation area and the buildings and curtilage are not statutorily or locally listed. The site is located in the Metrpolitan Open Land.No objections have been received.The application seeks to determine whether the prior approval of the Local Planning Authority is required for the siting and appearance of the installation of 20 metre high monopole supporting 6 no. antennas and 2 no. transmission dishes, 4 no. equipment cabinets and associated development worksThe application has been assessed against the provisions of Schedule 2 Part 16 of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 as amended. The application has also been assessed against the policies of the National Planning Policy Framework and the current Development Plan policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy.The National Planning Policy Framework 2021 is clear at paragraph 118 in as much as the Local Planning Authority should not question need. Local planning authorities must determine applications on planning grounds only. They should not seek to prevent competition between different operators, question the need for an electronic communications system, or set health safeguards different from the International Commission guidelines for public exposure.This application is for prior approval, not for planning permission. Prior approval is a light-touch process which applies where the principle of the development has already been established (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 028 Reference ID: 13-028-20140306).Prior approval means that a developer has to seek approval from the local planning authority that specified elements of the development are acceptable before work can proceed. The matters for prior approval vary depending on the type of development and these are set out in full in the relevant parts in Schedule 2 to the General Permitted Development Order. A local planning authority cannot consider any other matters when determining a prior approval application (National Planning Practice Guidance) (Paragraph: 026 Reference ID: 13-026-20140306).The main considerations of the case are: - Siting and; - AppearanceThe application is located in the designated Metropolitan Open Land which for the purposes of making an assessment in terms of land use is given the same status and assessed as Green Belt land.Section 336 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended) defines a building as any erection or structure. As such the proposed development, and associated equipment, would fall to be classed as a building(s).The NPPF directs that the erection of a building in the Green Belt would be inappropriate development save for a number of limited exceptions., these are listed in paras 149 and 150. The development proposed is not listed in either paragraph and as such is therefore inappropriate development in the Green Belt.Inappropriate development in the Green Belt is by definition harmful and should not be approved unless there are considerations which would clearly outweigh the harm to the Green Belt and any other harm so as to amount to very circumstances.Other than need, although no information has been put forward to robustly discount other locations, the applicant has not put forward any other considerations which, taken individually or cumulatively would clearly outweigh the harm to the Green Belt and any other harm so as to amount to very special circumstances.In addition to the definitional harm to the Green Belt, it is proposed to locate the mast on a prominent roadside junction. The proposed mast would be 20m in height which would be in excess of 10 to 12m higher than a standard telegraph pole (8m) and street lamp column (10m) which are typical of other such predominant perpendicular pieces of street furniture found in the locality and it is considered due to its appearance in particular its height it would be an incongruous addition that would be visually intrusive in the surrounding views of the site and detract from the character and appearance of the area.It is considered that the siting and appearance would not be appropriate for this location as it would both constitute inappropriate development in the Metropolitan Open Land and create an incongruous addition that would be visually intrusive in the surrounding views of the site and detract from the character and appearance of the area. It is recommended that the application be refused as it would not accord with paragraphs 147 - 151 of the National Planning Policy Framework and policies CS8, DM5 and DM10 of the Council's adopted LDF Core Strategy April 2012.The need for an upgraded, modern telecommunications network is both acknowledged and appreciated, and indeed is given great weight in the decision making process; however, for the reasons cited above it is considered that the harm caused by the proposed installation would outweigh the benefits.In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

The site is occupied by a two storey semi detached dwelling and single garage to the side.4 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 2 representations have been received. One in support of the proposal and one with concerns regarding a loss of light.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development; - The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- Flood risk.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed single storey rear extension would accord with the height parameters set by the Residential Design SPD, and would replace an existing single storey pitched roof structure to the rear, with a full width rendered, pitched roof extension. The proposed extension would also be lower in height than the existing structure located on the boundary with No.106 Cheshire Gardens, and would maintain the same building line as it relates to this property.  Although the extension would project beyond the neighbouring property at No.102 Cheshire Gardens, officers acknowledge that the projection is modest, and given the considered scale and external finish of the proposed extension it is unlikely to result in any harm to the overall character and appearance of the surrounding area. Overall, the proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: The proposed extension would maintain the same depth as it relates to No.106 Cheshire Gardens and be lower in height than the existing building on the shared boundary. The extension would project beyond No.102 Cheshire Gardens, however officers acknowledge it is a modest projection and the extension would accord with the parameters of the SPD in relation to height. The plans also demonstrate compliance with the 45 degree daylight and sunlighting criteria of the SPD.  It is therefore considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance or loss of light/sunlight. Flood RiskPolicy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM4 of the Council's Core strategy 2012 require development proposals to accord with the flood risk policies set out in the NPPF.The site is located within Flood Zone 2. The applicant has submitted a site-specific flood risk assessment which sets out that floor levels within the extensions would be set no lower than existing and flood proofing of the development has been incorporated where appropriate in order to mitigate the risk of flooding to occupiers of the development. Officers note the flood zone relates to the very rear of the application property. Given the modest scale of the development and the above it is considered the development would not exacerbate the current risk posed to the existing built environment.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2019), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.12 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and 2 objections from one household have been received relating to the effect on trees. The concerns raised will be taken into consideration during the assessment of the application and detailed below.The key areas of assessment are: - The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; - The impact of the proposed development on protected trees on site; and,- The impact of the proposed development on highways and transportation matters.Tree and Landscape Officer - No objection subject to conditionsProposal Officers note that the current application is a revision of previously refused application ref: 21/01529/HOU. The principal issue with the refused application was that the proposal did not provide adequate information to ensure that there would be no adverse impact to protected trees on site. The applicant has provided the relevant supporting information in elation to this matter and it will be further considered in this assessment. Officers acknowledge that the scheme subject of this application and in comparion to the previously refused scheme proposes no design amendements. Character and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: While the two storey side extension would not strictly accord with the parameters of the Residential Design SPD, the development would be set back from the front elevation and would retain the catslide roof feature. The proposed part single, part two storey rear extension would be inkeeping with the original dwelling in terms of roof forms, bulk, scale and mass. Overall, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. AmenityThe proposed single storey rear extension would have a depth that exceeds the parameters set out in the Residential Design SPD, however, given the context of the site, it would not appear a disproportionate addition to the host property or out of keeping with the character of the surrounding area.The proposed part two storey rear extension would have a roof form that is in keeping with the original dwelling, and would be set in appropriately from the shared boundaries. As such, it is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the original building or the immediate surrounding area as a result of the proposed development. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officer Comment: Given the proximity of the development in relation to neighbouring properties, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light/sunlight. While openings are proposed to the side elevation at first floor level, officers consider that a condition can be imposed if the development were to be approved to mitigate any loss of privacy for neighbouring properties.TreesPolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) states that The Council will expect new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders are not adversely affected. Policy Guidance 7 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) state that generally there will be a presumption against the loss of trees - regardless of whether they are protected by virtue of a Tree Preservation Order or with respect to their location within a designated Conservation Area.Officer Comment: Officers are satisfied that the submitted Arboricultural Method Statement and Tree Protection Plan provided in support of the application would ensure that the proposed development would not adversely affect the health or longevity of protected trees on site.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: While the hardstanding to the side of the dwellinghouse would be reduced as a result of the proposed development, officers note that there is sufficient hardstanding to the front of the dwelling to retain at least 2 car parking spaces. Whilst this level of provision would be in excess of the maximum car parking satndards set out in the London Plan, Officer consider that this issue would not warrant grounds for refusal given that it is reflective of the existing situation.London Plan policy T5 requires all development to include provision for cycle parking. As the side access to the rear of the dwelling would be significantly narrowed, officers consider that there would be insufficient space to access the rear garden and secure cycle storage options therein. As such officers consider that a condition requesting cycle parking details be attached to any grant of planning permission to ensure compliance.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey semi detached building.ProposalPlanning permission is sought for the erection of a single storey rear extension. Consultation 12 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. Character and Appearance Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. The proposed extension would accord with the height parameters for flat roof rear extensions set out in the SPD, and although it would project further than 3.5m from the existing rear building line, it would align with the neighbouring property (which forms a pair with the application property) at No.11 Neville Road. The extension would project beyond the rear building line of No.15 Neville Road, however, the buildings are physically separated  and the extension would be in keeping with other rear building lines/extensions evident along this part of Neville Road. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the character and appearance of the area would be acceptable.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed extension would match the depth of the neighbouring property at No.11 Neville Road. To No.15 Neville Road, the extension would maintain the existing setback (set back from the boundary) and is of an acceptable height (in accordance with SPD requirements) with no windows proposed to the side elevation.  Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.ConclusionHaving regard to the above, officers consider the proposal to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be refused, officers conclude that planning permission should be granted.

Application SiteThe application site is occupied by a two storey semi detached building.ProposalThe application seeks permission for the erection of a single storey rear extension.Consultation5 properties were notified of the proposal. One representation has been received objecting to the proposal. No other details were provided other than stating an objection.AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Rear ExtensionThe proposed single storey ground floor side extension would not accord with the parameters of the SPD projecting 9m from the rear wall of the existing building in an 'L' shape design along the boundary shared with No.14 Durbin Road and 1.2m with the opposite boundary shared with No.18 Durbin Road. Officers acknowledge the existing outbuildings on site and those on the neighbouring property at No.14 Durbin Road however these structures are not connected to the host buildings, and the proposed extension would have a larger footprint/building envelope than currently exists, and would set an unwanted precedent for a pattern of development that is not characteristic of the surrounding area. There is also no other evidence or justification to warrant approval for an extension of this nature.  The combined depth and siting of the proposed extension are not therefore considered to represent a development that respects the existing pattern of development, and the built form of neighbouring properties.Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have an unacceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The siting and the depth of the proposed extension in relation to No.14 Durbin Road is unsatisfactory however any sense of enclosure or loss of outlook may be largely mitigated by the existing outbuildings located on this property.  There are windows proposed to the side elevation of the proposed extension however these could be obscured by condition to ensure no loss of privacy to the occupants of No.18 Durbin Road. ConclusionHaving regard to the above, officers consider the proposal would not to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole. In the absence of any other material considerations which indicate that permission should be approved, officers conclude that planning permission should be refused.

Development demand has been modelled taking the 8" in Dickerage Lane as POC.The impact at the lowest pressure point in DMA ZSUR3015 on Crown Road (Coombe Hill) is 0.3m. Pressures at thispoint are around 15m. The pressure reduction at the POC is 0.7m at peak demand. The fire hydrant on the 8" onDickerage Lane near the POC can supply 25 l/s and maintain the required residual pressure. As a result,reinforcements are NOT required.

Unless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remainconsistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

The assessment has been based on the original layout of the house which shows stepped rear elevation. The proposed extension would therefore extend beyond the side elevation of the original footprint and would have a width greater than half the width of the original dwellinghouse, in conflict with Paragraph A.1 (j) (iii) of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order 2015 (as amended).

If you have evidence to contradict the local planning authority's assessment of the application, you are encouraged to apply for the development again and include that evidence in support of the application.

In dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

The applicant is informed that the submitted details for Condition 25 (Thames Water Network Upgrades) of planning permission 19/01228/FUL have been assessed and are hereby approved subject to carrying out the development in accordance with the approved details.

The fee required for your planning application is  234.00.  Payment can be made via either our Contact Centre on 0208 547 5002, by cheque made payable to Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames or online via the Kingston council website.Please note that you are not entitled to a free go on this application as the application type differs.Under the Town and Country Planning (Fees for Applications, Deemed Applications, Requests and Site Visits) (England) Regulations 2012 a 'free go' is only applicable If the proposal is the first revision of an application for development of the same character or description on the same site by the same applicant within 12 months of making the earlier application if withdrawn or the date of decision if granted or refused (including signs only if withdrawn or refused) and NOT a duplicate application made by the same applicant within 28 days.
